title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, by replacing "Reauthorization Act of 1994" with "Accountability and Reform Act of 1995". The amendment to Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, requires specific information from a credible source to determine the need for a preliminary investigation within 15 days of receiving the information. The Attorney General must determine the need for a preliminary investigation within 15 days of receiving credible information, closing the matter if there is insufficient evidence of a violation, commencing an investigation if there is sufficient evidence, or extending the period if unable to make a determination. The Attorney General must commence a preliminary investigation within 15 days of receiving specific information from a credible source regarding a violation. If unable to determine sufficiency within that period, the investigation will still proceed. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel under title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify limitations to alleged criminal law violations and related matters. The independent counsel is granted authority to fully investigate and prosecute within defined prosecutorial jurisdiction. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel under title 28, United States Code, is amended to ensure adequate authority to investigate and prosecute alleged criminal law violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel is amended to investigate and prosecute criminal violations such as perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and witness intimidation. Amendments to title 28, United States Code, clarify the scope of criminal law violations that can be pursued. The authorities and duties of the independent counsel are outlined in Section 5. The independent counsel is entitled to office space within a Federal building, provided by the Administrator of General Services. Amendments to Section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code, include ensuring compliance with Department of Justice policies regarding the enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information relating to criminal proceedings. The code is amended to specify that enforcement of criminal laws must occur at all times. Prior amendments to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code, are repealed. A limitation on expenditures for independent counsel offices is set at a 2-year period after establishment. Limitation on Expenditures: No funds may be spent on independent counsel offices after 2 years of establishment, unless specified in a later appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow removal of independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to allow termination of an independent counsel office by the court under certain conditions. The independent counsel can be removed or terminated under certain conditions, including completion of the investigation or prosecution not being in the public interest. Monthly expenditures are also addressed in the amendment. The independent counsel can be removed if the investigation or prosecution is not in the public interest. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. Periodic reappointment of the independent counsel is also addressed. The amendment made by paragraph (1) will take effect at the end of the 1st month after the enactment of the Act. Section 596 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for the periodic reappointment of independent counsel every 2 years. The court will decide on reappointment based on the termination of the counsel's office. The court will decide on reappointment of the independent counsel every 2 years based on termination criteria. If the office is not terminated, the court will reappoint the current counsel if deemed appropriate, otherwise, a qualified person will be appointed. If the court fails to take action within 90 days after the 2-year period, the office will terminate. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, with recommendations to improve cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
